content:
• Tuesday, February 20, 2018
  • FE

    FirstEnergy +3% after Q4 earnings beat, 2018 earnings guidance

    • FirstEnergy (NYSE:FE) +3% after-hours as it beats Q4 earnings estimates with revenues unchanged from the year-ago period at $3.4B.
    • FE introduces 2018 regulated operating EPS guidance of $2.25-$2.55, and forecasts compound annual growth for its regulated operations, excluding the Ohio DMR and offset by the corporate segment, of 6%-8% through 2021, which includes $10B-plus in regulated capital investments planned over the period.
    • FE says it took a Q4 pretax charge of $2.4B from plant writedowns and other exit costs after $9.22B in charges in the year-earlier quarter related to its planned exit from the money-losing competitive power generation business.
    • The U.S. corporate tax cut to 21% from 35% also reduced earnings by $1.2B pretax, similar to reductions experienced by Duke Energy and other utilities, according to Bloomberg's Kit Konolige.
    • Also, FE announces Donald Misheff was named Chairman as well as several management changes, including James Pearson as Executive VP of Finance, Steven Strah as Senior VP and CFO, and Samuel Belcher as Senior VP and president of FirstEnergy Utilities.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:47 PM
  • ANW

    Aegean Marine sees $0.69/share Q4 loss; shares -5.5%

    • Aegean Marine Petroleum (OTC:ANW) -5.5% after-hours, saying it expects to report a Q4 loss of ~$28.2M, or a loss of $0.69/share, including $14.5M of non-recurring charges; the company plans to release earnings on March 7.
    • ANW says expected Q4 headline results "do not tell the full story of the cost cutting and bold steps we have taken, such as ceasing our physical supply business in Singapore during the quarter," ANW says. "2018 is likely to be another tough year for our core business, but Aegean is amidst a transformation that we firmly believe will unlock significant value for all shareholders over time."
    • ANW also says it agrees to acquire port reception facilities services company H.E.C. Europe Ltd. for $367M, including debt; the company expects the deal to be immediately accretive to adjusted EPS.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:14 PM | 12 Comments
  • CXO

    Concho Resources lower despite Q4 earnings beat, upbeat production view

    • Concho Resources (NYSE:CXO) -2.7% after-hours despite posting better than expected Q4 earnings and forecasting a 16%-20% Y/Y increase in 2018 total production.
    • CXO says it delivered total production of 211K boe/day during Q4, exceeding the high end of its guidance range and 28% above year-ago levels, while crude oil production of 130K boe/day rose 30% Y/Y; for FY 2017, total production rose 28% Y/Y to 193K boe/day, driven by a 29% increase in crude oil production to 119K boe/day.
    • At year-end 2017, estimated proved reserves of 840M boe (60% oil, 40% natural gas) rose 17% Y/Y, and proved developed reserves totaled 588M boe, up 26% from year-end 2016.
    • CXO expects 2018 capex of $1.9B-$2.1B, higher than its 2017 guidance of $1.6B-$1.8B.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:57 PM | 3 Comments
  • DVN

    Devon Energy -4% after wide Q4 earnings miss, lower full-year production

    • Devon Energy (NYSE:DVN) -4.7% after-hours as it widely misses Q4 earnings expectations even while revenues rose 41% to $3.98B, which beat estimates.
    • DVN says Q4 total production inched higher to 548K boe/day from 537M boe/day in the year-ago quarter, but FY 2017 output fell to 543K boe/day from 611K boe/day in 2017, citing delayed well tie-ins in the U.S. and steam-plant problems in its Canadian operations.
    • DVN says early 2018 production growth has accelerated in its Delaware Basin and STACK assets, where combined current daily rates are ~195K boe/day.
    • DVN forecasts production of 530K-554K boe/day for Q1, and 552K-576K boe/day for FY 2018; estimated proved reserves totaled 2.2B boe at year-end 2017, up 5% Y/Y.
    • Over the next three years, DVN says it foresees greater than 15% corporate-level rates of return, $2.5B of cumulative free cash flow, Delaware and STACK oil production compound annual growth topping 25%, and ~15% in per-unit cash cost savings  by 2020.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:39 PM | 19 Comments
  • SHOP

    Shopify -3.7% on offering of subordinate voting shares

    • Shopify (NYSE:SHOP) is 3.7% lower in postmarket trading after launching an offering of its class A subordinate voting shares.
    • It will sell 4.8M of the shares in the offering, to be conducted by joint book-runners Credit Suisse and Morgan Stanley, and co-manager National Bank.
    • The shares are said to be offered at $137-$140 each, Bloomberg reports; with closing price at $142.78, that represents a discount of roughly 2% to 4.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:37 PM | 43 Comments

    • Mindbody closed today up 2%.

  • FLR

    Fluor +3% after easy Q4 earnings beat

    • Fluor (NYSE:FLR) +3.3% after-hours as it easily beats Q4 earnings expectations and hits $5B in revenues for the quarter, saying 2017 new awards totaled $12.6B with year-end backlog of $31B.
    • FLR also issues FY 2018 earnings guidance, seeing EPS of $3.10-$3.50 but the figure includes $0.75-0.95 from tax reform and may not be comparable to the $2.56 analyst consensus estimate.
    • FLR says its biggest segment - Energy, Chemicals & Mining - reports a $455M profit vs. a $401M segment profit in 2016, while segment revenue for 2017 was $9.4B, down from $9.8B in 2016, primarily due to the completion of certain chemicals projects.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:31 PM | 6 Comments
  • LC

    LendingClub down 7% after miss, soft guidance

    • Q4 adjusted EBITDA of $19M vs. $20.9M in Q3 and a loss of $900K a year ago.
    • Originations of $2.483B about flat from Q3, and up from $1.987B a year ago. Full-year originations of $8.987B vs. $8.664B in 2016.
    • Q1 revenue expected to be $145M-$155M, shy of consensus $161M. Full-year 2018 revenue seen at $680M-$705M vs. estimates of $695.6M. Adjusted EBITDA seen at $75M-$90M vs. $44.6M in 2017.
    • Company also will settle (subject to court approval) legacy issues for $125M, with $47.75M of that covered by insurance. The remained is reflected in Q4 GAAP results, and will be paid with cash on hand.
    • Conference call at 5 ET
    • Previously: LendingClub misses by $0.01, misses on revenue (Feb. 20)
    • LC -6.8% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:21 PM | 13 Comments

  • RCKY

    Margins improve at Rocky Brands

    • Rocky Brands (NASDAQ:RCKY) reports sales came in flat during Q4 at $67.0M.
    • Gross margin improved to 34.8% of sales vs. 32.5% a year ago.
    • SG&A expenses fell 50 bps to 29.3% of sales.
    • Operating income was 6.0% of sales vs. 2.8% a year ago.
    • CEO update: "We concluded a productive 2017 with a very solid fourth quarter performance which was highlighted by mid-single digit growth for both our wholesale and retail divisions. The product, marketing and distribution strategies we’ve recently implemented aimed at increasing full-price selling for our branded work, western and outdoor footwear businesses are contributing to better top and bottom line results."
     
     
     
     
    | 4:15 PM | 5 Comments

  • AXAS

    Abraxas Petroleum says 2017 proved reserves rose 47%

    • Abraxas Petroleum (AXAS +2.1%) is higher after reporting year-end 2017 proved oil and natural gas reserves rose 47.5% Y/Y to 65.9M boe from 44.7M boe at the end of 2016.
    • AXAS says reserves consisted of ~37.6M barrels of oil, 12M barrels of natural gas liquids and 97.8B cf of natural gas.
    • PDP reserves were 20.7M boe, up 48.5% Y/Y, and comprised 31.4% of proved reserves as of Dec. 31.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM
  • W

    Wayfair hits triple digits

    • Shares of Wayfiar (W -1.1%) shot past $100 for the first time today before falling back later in the day.
    • It doesn't take a whole lot to get buying activity whipped up on the retailer, and today it was a note from Wedbush (Outperform, $98 PT) lighting a spark.
    • Wedbush sees "material upside" on Wayfair exceeding Q4 consensus estimates when it reports on Feb. 22.
    • Wayfair is +135% over the last 52 weeks.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:54 PM | 7 Comments
  • BABA

    Alibaba buys 15% stake of furniture chain for $851M

    • Alibaba (NYSE:BABA) buys a 15% stake in Chinese furniture chain Easyhome for $851M.
    • Alibaba will assist Easyhome in developing sales spaces and distribution networks. 
    • Easyhome operated 223 stores at the end of last year with annual sales topping $9.5B. 
    • Easyhome wants to raise the store count to at least 600 by 2022 with a sales goal of $15.8B. 
    • Alibaba shares are up 1.7%.  
     
     
     
     
    | 3:54 PM | 18 Comments
  • WIZP

    Wize Pharma on go with Phase 4 study of LO2A in dry eye syndrome; shares up 17%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Wize Pharma (OTCQB:WIZP +16.7%) is up on average volume on the heels of its announcement that it has received Institutional Review Board (IRB) approval for the protocol of a Phase 4 study evaluating LO2A against Alcon's Systane Ultra UD, both eye drops, in 60 adult Sjögren's syndrome patients with dry eyes.
    • Enrollment should commence this quarter but the company says it lacks the funds to pay for the study. Nothing will happen until the company raises new capital.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:35 PM | 1 Comment

    Virtu works higher alongside volatility

    • VIRT is up 64% YTD, nearly mirroring the 60% gain in VXX.
    • Previously: Virtu Financial gets bump from Mark Cuban (Feb. 13)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:25 PM | 4 Comments
  • DUK

    Duke Energy to sell $2B of stock this year, thanks to tax cuts

    • Duke Energy's (DUK -1.4%) plans to sell $2B of stock this year, in part to make up for the financial impact of recent tax reforms on its cash flow as it passes savings from the lower tax rates to customers, sent shares lower today by as much as 2.5% before recouping some of the losses.
    • DUK’s equity sale would be as much as $1.65B more than the company was contemplating before the corporate rate cuts, CFO Steve Young tells Bloomberg.
    • “Because Duke Energy is not a significant cash taxpayer, any reduction to customer rates will place downward pressure on our consolidated cash flows,” Young says.
    • The new issuance and the weak guidance - DUK forecasts 2018 adjusted EPS of $4.55-$4.85, below its plans to grow earnings by 4%-6% annually through 2022 - also are causing investors to lower their expectations for 2018, says Guggenheim Securities analyst Shahriar Pourreza, although the company expects to resume its planned earnings growth next year.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:14 PM | 13 Comments
  • WDC

    RBC calls Western Digital an "attractive LBO candidate"

    • RBC Capital calls Western Digital (NYSE:WDC) “an attractive LBO candidate.”
    • Analyst Amit Daryanani notes the multiple PE firms involved in the Toshiba chip unit sale to the Bain-led consortium. 
    • The analyst writes that Western Digital stock is “at ~6x EV/FCF (fourth cheapest in S&P500).” 
    • Daryanani reiterates an Outperform rating and $115 price target with a suggested takeout price of $105. 
    • Western Digital shares are up 1.7% to $86.37.     
     
     
     
     
    | 3:11 PM | 15 Comments
  • GE

    GE -2% as Barron's cover story warns of further 10% stock drop

    • General Electric (GE -2%) sinks following a weekend Barron's cover story that warns business challenges facing the company could send shares down another 10% or more.
    • Among the headwinds cited in the article: The stock does not look cheap based on a sum-of-the-parts analysis; weak trends in GE’s power business could put 2018 earnings at risk; the market for natural gas turbines for electric utilities is in decline as a result of the growth of increasingly cheap solar and wind power; and ghosts of businesses past - such as the old insurance contracts that caused GE to take a $9.5B pretax charge - continue to haunt the company.
    • One reason it is hard to have confidence in GE, says Deutsche Bank's John Inch, is the dramatic decline in the company’s financial guidance: GE a year ago still talked about generating $2/share in 2018 EPS but its current guidance is $1.00-$1.07, with Wall Street consensus even lower at $0.98, and while many of the company's peers are generating strong growth, GE’s organic sales were down 6% in Q4.
    • "If GE is dumped from the Dow industrials, bulls would seize on that as a sign of a bottom," writes Barron's Andrew Bary. "Yet a close look at GE suggests the stock isn’t cheap based on earnings, a sum-of-the-parts analysis, leverage, complexity, and business challenges. GE’s best days may lie in the past."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:57 PM | 103 Comments

  • GOLD

    Gold posts biggest daily drop in more than a year

    • Gold prices settle -1.9% at $1,331.20/oz. for the sharpest daily decline since December 2016, as the dollar continues its rebound from a brutal selloff in recent weeks and many Asian investors - big buyers in gold - continue to observe Lunar New Year, dampening buying momentum.
    • But gold could get a boost as the U.S. government launches a series of auctions for $258B worth of debt this week; "if there is less than the required appetite for that mountain of debt, that could weaken the dollar and support gold," says Ole Storer, head of commodity strategy at Saxo Bank in Copenhagen. "That leads me to believe that any correction in gold will continue to be a buying opportunity at this stage."
    • Among top precious metals stocks: ABX -1.8%, GG -2%, KGC -2.3%, NEM -1.8%, EGO -1.8%, AEM -2.7%, RGLD -3.7%, AUY -3.7%, GFI -3.3%, AU -4.3%, FNV -1.6%, WPM -1.6%.
    • ETFs: GLD, SLV, GDX, NUGT, GGN, DUST, IAU, AGQ, PSLV, SIL, PHYS, USLV, SIVR, SGOL, GOEX, UGLD, ZSL, SGDM, UGL, SLVO, DGP, GLL, ASA, GTU, GLDI, OUNZ, SLVP, DSLV, RING, DZZ, DGL, DGLD, TGLDX, DBS, DGZ, PSAU, GOAU, GDXX, GYEN, BAR, GEUR, GDXS, GLDW, GHS, UBG, USV, SHNY, QGLDX, GHE, MELT, DULL

    Hewlett Packard Enterprise gets $57M supercomputer contract

    • The supercomputers are under the DoD High Performance Computing Modernization Program to accelerate advanced national security capabilities.

  • KIRK

    Promotional pressure dings profit at Kirkland's

    • Kirkland's (KIRK -16.2%) falls sharply after an increase in promotional activity led to a Q4 profit miss.
    • "Store traffic slowed in the latter half of the quarter as we experienced a further shift in holiday shopping patterns, and that resulted in a higher-than-expected level of promotional activity," notes CEo Mike Madden. "The related merchandise margin pressure impacted fourth quarter earnings, despite operating expenses that were in line with expectations," he adds.
    • The company sees full-year EPS of $0.32 to $0.34 vs. $0.59 consensus.
    • Shares of Kirkland's traded as low as $9.85 earlier.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:11 PM

  • SLNO

    Soleno on go with late-stage study of DCCR for rare metabolic disorder; shares up 4%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Soleno Therapeutics (SLNO +4.3%) is up, albeit on below-average volume, on the heels of its announcement that it and the FDA are aligned with the key aspects of a planned Phase 3 study evaluating Diazoxide Choline Controlled-Release (DCCR) for the treatment of Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS), a rare inherited disorder characterized by weak muscle tone, feeding difficulties, poor growth and delayed development. Sufferers are frequently obese from overeating because they constantly feel hungry. The study should commence in the near future.
    • DCCR is a crystalline salt of diazoxide, a potassium channel activator (a vasodilator) which causes smooth muscle to relax by increasing membrane permeability to potassium ions. Teva Pharmaceutical Industries markets diazoxide free base under the brand name PROGLYCEM for the treatment of low blood sugar.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:49 PM | 3 Comments

    Obalon "all clear" after completing inquiry into possible improper FQ4 revenue recognition; shares up 6%

    | 1:28 PM | 1 Comment
  • AET

    HHS debuts new rule allowing increased access to short-term insurance plans

    • The Trump administration has released a new rule that will allow Americans greater access to short-term health insurance plans, specifically allowing people to buy health insurance coverage for up to one year.
    • Under the Affordable Care Act , or Obamacare, short-term plans, intended to fill gaps in coverage due to events such as job loss, cannot be used for more than three months.
    • The new short-term plans offer pared-down benefits and do not have to abide by all Obamacare regulations. For example, the plans can charge higher premiums based on medical history, cap the amount of benefits and do not have to offer the 10 baseline types of care.
    • The plans will cost less upfront, but critics say they will siphon more healthy people from Obamacare thereby driving up costs for sicker patients who remain since the risk pool will be smaller. Middle-class enrollees could be hit especially hard since they are don't receive the same level of subsidies as lower-income beneficiaries.
    • Selected tickers: (AET -0.2%)(CI -0.5%)(UNH -0.6%)(HUM -0.8%)(UHS -0.8%)(LPNT -0.5%)(CYH -0.5%)(XBI -0.2%)(VHT -0.2%)(XLV -0.5%)(BME -0.2%)(IXJ -0.6%)(THW -0.4%)(GRX -1.1%)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:16 PM | 51 Comments

  • GPS

    Gap brand president steps down

    • Gap (GPS -3.3%) announces that Gap brand CEO Jeff Kirwan is leaving the company.
    • "While I am pleased with our progress in brand health and product quality, we have not achieved the operational excellence and accelerated profit growth that we know is possible at Gap brand.   • DUK

    Duke Energy -2% as tax reform seen trimming 2018 earnings growth

    • Duke Energy (DUK -1.9%) is lower after Q4 earnings beat analyst expectations but revenues fall short, and the company says FY 2018 earnings may come in below its long-term growth projections.
    • DUK forecasts FY 2018 EPS will take a ~$0.13 hit from the recent U.S. tax changes, largely because of a reduction in the value of tax benefits of financing at the corporate level as the tax rate declines to 21% from 35%.
    • "Absent tax reform, our organic businesses were growing at 5% and our 2016 midpoint of $4.60 would have moved up in 2018 to about $4.83 per share,” CFO Steve Young says; with the reduction due to tax reform, the midpoint would be at ~$4.70/share.
    • DUK adjusted its 2018 EPS outlook accordingly, seeing FY 2018 EPS of $4.55-$4.85 vs. $4.78 analyst consensus estimate, which would place earnings on average below its 4%-6% long-term growth outlook off the original 2017 midpoint of $4.60/share.

  • WVE

    Wave Life Sciences teams up with Takeda to develop CNS treatments

    • Wave Life Sciences (WVE -5.6%) inks a global collaboration with Takeda Pharmaceutical Company (OTCPK:TKPHF -2.4%) aimed at developing and commercializing nucleic acid therapies for central nervous system (CNS) disorders. Takeda will have the right to co-develop and co-commercialize programs in Huntington's disease (HD), amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), frontotemporal dementia (FTD), and spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 (SCA3).
    • Under the terms of the two-component agreement, Takeda will pay Wave $110M upfront and purchase $60M of Wave's ordinary shares at $54.70 per share. Takeda will also provide at least $60M of research funding over a four-year period.
    • The first component allows Takeda the option to co-develop/co-commercialize WVE-120101 and WVE-120102 in HD, WVE-3972-01 in ALS and FTD and a program in SCA3 after Wave demonstrates proof of mechanism. If Takeda opts in, Wave will receive an opt-in payment and will lead manufacturing and co-development activities. Takeda will lead co-development in the U.S. and all commercial activities ex-U.S. Global costs and profits will be equally shared. Wave will be eligible to receive development and commercial milestone payments.
    • The second component provides Takeda the right to license multiple preclinical programs for CNS indications, including Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's. During a four-year term, the companies may collaborate on up to six targets at any time. Takeda will provide at least $60M to help fund Wave's preclinical activities and additional expenses. If Takeda elects to advance six programs, Wave will be eligible to receive more than $2B in milestones. Wave will also be eligible to receive tiered high single-digit-to-mid-teen royalties on global net sales.
    • Wave will continue its development efforts in neuromuscular diseases, including Duchenne muscular dystrophy, independently.
    • Wave is down in what appears to be "sell the news" action. Shares had run up almost 40% before the announcement.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:12 PM

  • QCOM

    Broadcom: Qualcomm's boosted NXP offer a unilateral value transfer

    • In a response to Qualcomm's (NASDAQ:QCOM) boosted bid for NXP Semiconductors, hostile Qualcomm suitor Broadcom (NASDAQ:AVGO) says it's evaluating its options after a "transfer of value" from Qualcomm to NXP.
    • "By raising its offer for NXP from $110 per NXP share to $127.50 per NXP share, Qualcomm's board of directors and management have transferred $4.10 per Qualcomm share from Qualcomm stockholders to NXP stockholders, representing approximately $6.2 billion of value," Broadcom says in a statement, adding that the price increase marks a disregard for fiduciary duty.
    • "In light of Qualcomm's decision to transfer value from its own stockholders to NXP stockholders, Broadcom is evaluating its options."
    • AVGO is up 2.3%; QCOM, meanwhile, is 3.3% lower.
    • Institutional Shareholder Services has recommended a vote on the blue proxy card for four of Broadcom's six director nominees, what it suggests is a reasonable path toward a negotiated deal.
    • Glass Lewis, meanwhile, is urging a vote for all six Broadcom nominees. Qualcomm "consistently dragged its feet" in engaging on the deal, and that lack of effort should concern investors, the firm says.
